narrative: Maya stepped onto the Martian surface, her boots crunching into the rust-colored dirt.
The weird landscape stretched forever under an orange sky that looked nothing like Earth.
She planted the mission flag and turned on her radio to let everyone back home know she'd made it safely.

options.text: Look for places where water used to flow

consequences.text: Maya's rock scanner found crystals that only form when there's water around... these rocks were millions of years old!
She found what looked like old dried-up riverbeds carved right into the ground... water definitely used to flow here.

continuation: Her scanner kept beeping at mineral stuff that showed water had been all over this place once.
Everything Maya found proved that Mars used to be totally different... warm, wet, and maybe even perfect for life.
As Maya kept exploring, she realized she was finding stuff that would blow everyone's minds.
Her discoveries were going to help scientists figure out if humans could actually live on Mars someday.

reflections.question: How do you think it would feel to be completely alone on another planet, finding things no human had ever seen?
If you could explore any planet, what would you most want to discover there?

narrative: Maya had just done something no teenager ever had... she was actually standing on Mars as the mission commander.
The red, empty landscape was so different from Earth's green and blue colors, and it reminded her how far from home she really was.
Her geological equipment immediately started picking up interesting mineral readings that suggested water had been active here way back in Mars's history.

choice_points.question: How should Maya focus her research?

options.text: Study the geology to understand how Mars formed and changed
Search for signs that life might have existed here

consequences.text: The geological data revealed incredible evidence of volcanoes, asteroid impacts, and massive climate changes that transformed Mars over billions of years.
Maya's systematic search turned up organic compounds in the rock layers... the exact kind of molecules that could mean ancient life existed here.

continuation: Maya made sure to follow all the scientific procedures so every sample and measurement would be super valuable for researchers back on Earth.
The data painted an amazing picture of Mars as a world that once had flowing rivers, huge oceans, and conditions where life could actually survive.
Her discoveries would shape how scientists plan future Mars missions and maybe even colonies.
Standing alone on another planet, Maya had become humanity's first real ambassador to another world.

reflections.question: When you're working on something important by yourself, what keeps you motivated and focused?
How would you prepare yourself for a challenging mission that no one has ever done before?

narrative: Maya was running the most advanced Mars exploration mission humans had ever attempted, using cutting-edge equipment designed to totally change what we know about the planet's history.
The mission combined years of planning with incredible technology that could analyze the atmosphere, drill underground, and examine rocks in ways never possible before.
Early readings suggested Mars had gone through complex changes involving volcanoes, asteroid hits, and climate shifts that created different environments where life might have been possible.

choice_points.question: Which research strategy should guide Maya's exploration?

options.text: Map out comprehensive geological surveys to track how the planet evolved
Focus on targeted biological investigations in areas most likely to have supported life

consequences.text: Maya's systematic geological mapping revealed totally unknown mineral formations that documented how Mars transformed from a potentially livable world to what it is today.
Her focused biological analysis detected complex organic molecules and chemical signatures that were consistent with life processes in multiple underground locations.

continuation: Maya's careful methods turned out to be way better than what other scientists had tried before, and her discoveries proved that a lot of textbooks were completely wrong about Mars.
The data showed that Mars could have supported life for millions of years longer than anyone thought possible.
Maya's mission changed everything scientists thought they knew about how planets work and whether life could exist elsewhere.
Through careful work and amazing discoveries, Maya had basically rewritten what humans understand about our solar system.

reflections.question: How do you think making discoveries that change what scientists believe would affect how responsible you feel about sharing your findings?
What scientific skills would you want to develop to contribute to space exploration and research about other planets?
